Description: Mould-made lamp with monogram on base. This is a pale grey clay oil lamp with no base and almost egg-shaped. It is relatively shallow and has a small hole in the centre, and a hole at the narrower end. It has an incised diamond with a dot in the centre on the base, and a moulded lined and raised circle decoration around the central hole, surrounded by an incised lined border. Pale buff Egyptian (?) marl fabric with common fine quartz and mica inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Part of 3rd to 4th century AD Egyptian ‘frog lamp’ group with moulded decoration of a frog that has the lamp nozzle in place of its head all in a buff clay (Bailey 1988, British Museum Lamps III, Q2137; Bailey 1998, no. X14). Bailey warns that late 2nd or early 3rd century AD ‘frog lamps’ from Myos Hormos (Whitcomb & Johnson 1982, pl.60dd) and from el-Ashmunein (Bailey 1998, pl.87 X13), suggest these have also been made before the 3rd century AD. 3rd to 4th century AD parallel from Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA III.3). Bailey, D. 1998. Excavations at el-Ashmunein V: Pottery, Lamps and Glass of the Late Roman and Early Arab Periods.British Museum press: London. Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie : Éditions Neriton. Whitcomb, D.S. & Johnson, J.H. 1982. Quseir al-Qadim 1980. Malibu.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.59) (Phase 1)
